title: Engineering UiO-66-NH
for Toxic Gas Removal
abstract: was synthesized in a scaled batch of approximately 100 g. The material was then pressed into small pellets at pressures ranging from 5000 to 100000 psi to determine the effects on porosity and crystal structure. Nitrogen isotherm data and powder X-ray diffraction data indicate that the structure remains intact up to 25000 psi, with only a slight decrease in surface area. The structure exhibits significant degradation at pressures above 25000 psi. Subsequently, the powder was pressed at 5000 psi and then crushed and sieved into 20 × 40 mesh granules for evaluation against ammonia and cyanogen chloride in a breakthrough system simulating individual protection filters and respirator cartridges. The MOF showed capacity similar to that of a broad-spectrum carbon for both ammonia and cyanogen chloride; however, the breakthrough times, especially for cyanogen chloride, were dramatically reduced, likely as a result of mass-transfer limitations from the completely microporous MOF.
text: The ability to introduce active sites onto sorbents that are capable of reaction with both acidic and basic gases continues to be an area of interest. Specifically, many respirators used by emergency and/or military personnel require broad-spectrum chemical removal because of the wide variety of toxic chemicals used worldwide. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) requires chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear (CBRN) filters to provide protection against a wide variety of gases, including ammonia (NH
These two chemicals require different chemistries for removal. NH
is typically removed through interaction with acidic sites or hydrogen-bonding sites,
whereas CNCl requires hydrolysis and/or interaction with functional groups capable of reacting with the cyanide moiety.
Several studies on activated, impregnated carbons have demonstrated the ability to create conflicting chemistries on a single sorbent.

Yet, most of these efforts focus on postsynthetic impregnation techniques, creating a mobile active phase that shows poor aging characteristics as a result of deleterious interactions within the substrate.
Over the past decade, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been intensely studied for a variety of potential applications, including gas storage,
The ability to incorporate multiple functionalities

into the backbone of MOFs is a major advantage over traditional activated, impregnated carbons. The UiO-66 series of MOFs are of particular interest because of their stability toward moisture and acids.
, which contains amine pendant groups on benzene dicarboxylate linkers, is capable of postsynthetic modification, allowing for further tailoring of functionality.
However, even without modification, the amine groups provide hydrogen-bonding sites for NH
sorption, as well as possible reactive sites for CNCl.
Several studies have been conducted on how physical properties and performance are affected by pressurization and/or other methods of forming granules and particles.

We previously investigated the effects of pressure on CuBTC and UiO-66 MOFs at pressures ranging from 1000 to 10000 psi, with results indicating that the UiO-66 material does not show degradation in surface area or performance.
In this study, we investigated how pressure affects the physical properties and chemical removal performance of UiO-66-NH
, with the objective of forming particles for simulated filter breakthrough testing against NH
was chosen as a candidate material over UiO-66 because of its increased performance against ammonia (Figure S1,
was synthesized by modifying established methods for large scale.
Zirconium(IV) chloride (12 g) and water (3 mL) were added to 800 mL of

-dimethylformamide (DMF) and stirred until fully dissolved. 2-Aminoterephthalic acid (9.4 g) was added to 400 mL of DMF and stirred until fully dissolved. The solutions were mixed in a BüchiGlasUster Ecoclave 075 batch reactor with 1.6 L glass reactor vessel. The reactor was stirred at 500 RPM and held at 120 °C for 24 h. The pale yellow solid was isolated by filtration. Up to seven batches were mixed for subsequent steps.

Samples were purified by Soxhlet extraction with methanol for 24 h. Excess solvent was removed by heating in air at 85 °C. Removal of solvent from the pores was achieved by evacuating the samples to <50 mTorr and heating at 85 °C for 4 h and then at 150 °C for 18 h. The reaction yield after solvent removal was measured at 84%.
In the initial pressurization study, approximately 1 g of UiO-66-NH

powder was pressed into pellets using a Carver Press and 0.5-in. die at loads of 1000, 2000, 5000, and 20000 lbs, corresponding to pressures of approximately 5000, 10000, 25000, and 100000 psi, respectively. The pellets were then ground into powders to conduct appropriate characterization and performance studies. Subsequent pellets were made with a 1.5-in. die using approximately 5 g of UiO-66-NH

powder, made into granules using a Sepor jaw crusher, and then sieved to 20 × 40 mesh particles. A broad-spectrum carbon (BSC) was acquired from 3M (Minneapolis, MN) in a 20 × 40 mesh particle size distribution as a baseline for breakthrough performance.

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were recorded using a PANalytical X’Pert X-ray powder diffractometer with an X’celerator detector. Samples were scanned at 45 kV and 40 mA using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) and a step size of 2θ = 0.033° (10.08 s/step) over a 2θ range of 5–30°. Zero-background disks were used to minimize background scattering. PXRD patterns were processed using the Reflex module in Material Studio 6.1 by Accelrys.

Attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy data were collected on composites using a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer with a platinum accessory and a single-reflection diamond crystal. Sixteen scans from 4000 to 600 cm
were averaged, and the background was subtracted with a resolution of 4 cm

Nitrogen isotherm data were collected at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 1200 system. Samples were off-gassed at 120 °C under nitrogen for approximately 16 h. Surface area measurements were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and pore volume was calculated at a relative pressure of 0.975. Pore size distributions were calculated using density functional theory (DFT) and a carbon slit pore kernel. A silica–alumina standard run on the system exhibits less than 1% standard deviation on surface area measurements.
Microbreakthrough testing was conducted on a push system designed for evaluating small (∼20 mg) quantities of powders and has been described previously.
Test conditions are summarized in Table
. Sorbents were activated at 120 °C for 1 h in flowing dry air, equilibrated at the proper relative humidity (RH) for 2 h as applicable and then packed at a constant volume of approximately 50–55 mm

in a 4-mm-i.d. (nominal) fritted glass tube to a height of 4 mm. Each chemical was injected into a ballast and then pressurized; from the ballast, the chemical was delivered to either a dry or humidified air stream at a rate necessary to achieve the desired challenge concentration. Water vapor was delivered to the system through a saturator cell within a water bath. The challenge was dosed to a packed bed until saturation (effluent = feed), after which the materials were purged with air to evaluate desorption. Effluent concentrations were monitored using Hewlett-Packard (HP) 5890 gas chromatographs equipped with a flame ionization detector (CNCl) and a photoionization detector (NH

). Microbreakthrough graphs are plotted on a mass-weighted basis to account for differences in density. Loadings were calculated in moles per kilogram by integrating the breakthrough curves to saturation. The standard system error is approximately 10%.

and CNCl breakthrough testing was conducted using a push–pull-vented breakthrough system. Each gas was delivered directly from a cylinder through a mass flow controller and then mixed with a diluent air stream at a rate necessary to achieve the required challenge concentration. The diluent stream flow and humidity were controlled using a Miller-Nelson HCS-401 system. Test tubes were packed using a storm-filling method
to a depth of 1.0 cm, simulating full-scale individual protection filters. The NH

feed and effluent concentrations were monitored using a Miran 1A infrared detector and an Innova 1314 Photoacoustics Multigas monitor, respectively. The CNCl feed and effluent concentrations were measured using an HP5890 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. The breakthrough time was calculated when the effluent concentrations reached 17 and 8 mg/m
, corresponding to military toxic exposure limits for NH
presents the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, and Figure

presents the ATR-FTIR spectra for the as-synthesized and pressed samples. The materials pressed between 5000 and 25000 psi all show similar PXRD patterns, indicating that the structural integrity and crystal structure remain intact. The sample pressed at 100000 psi shows peaks with 2θ values similar to those pressed at lower pressure; however, the decreased signal-to-noise ratio, lower overall intensity, and peak broadening all indicate reduced crystallinity. Similarly, the FTIR-ATR spectra show no noticeable differences between the as-synthesized sample and those pressed up to 25000 psi, indicating that the functional groups remain intact. Yet, the UiO-66-NH
-100K sample shows significant reduction in several FTIR bands.
Nitrogen isotherm data were collected to determine the effects of pressurization on surface area and pore volume. The uptake curves and resulting pore size distributions are illustrated in Figure
; surface area and pore volume measurements are summarized in Table
. Initial losses in nitrogen uptake, and thus surface area and pore volume, are modest up to 25000 psi. The surface area of the as-synthesized sample was found to be 1182 m
/g, which is similar to values reported in the literature.
The total pore volume of 0.50 cm
/g is also similar to that reported by others.

Pressing the powder at 5000 and 10000 psi resulted in 5% and 14% decreases, respectively, in surface area but no noticeable trend in the change of total pore volume. Further increasing the pelletization pressure to 25000 psi decreased the surface area by approximately 26% and the total pore volume by approximately 12%. It is likely that these decreases in surface area are due to increased density from a loss in interparticle voids in the micropore regime during pelletization. A pressure of 100000 psi resulted in surface area and pore volume reductions of 83% and 74%, respectively. Even with these changes in surface area and pore volume, the pore size distribution remained consistent, even up to 100000 psi.
Figure 3. (Left) Nitrogen isotherm and (right) pore size distribution (logarithmic scale) data for pressed samples.
Table 2. Surface Areas and Pore Volumes of Powder and Pressed UiO-66-NH
Small-scale breakthrough testing on powders was conducted using NH
and CNCl to determine the effects of pressure on chemical uptake. Figure
breakthrough curves under dry and humid conditions, and Table
summarizes the loadings for each sample. A clear trend presents itself, with NH

uptake decreasing with increasing pelletization pressure under both dry and humid conditions. The as-synthesized sample provides the highest loading on a mass basis, with loadings of 3.3 mol/kg (0.056 g/g) and 2.9 mol/kg (0.082 g/g) under dry and humid conditions, respectively. The loadings themselves are lower than those on other MOFs such as CuBTC
analogues by several moles per kilogram but surpass those of other sorbents such as zeolite 13X and BPL activated carbon. Furthermore, the enhanced stability of UiO-66-NH
makes it favorable over other MOFs studied.
microbreakthrough curves under (left) dry and (right) humid conditions.
The overall trends seem logical, as the surface area and pore volume also decrease with increasing pressure, resulting in less availability of active sites for NH
sorption. Based on the shape of the desorption curves, it appears that the removal mechanism is not permanent, as NH
continues to elute for a relatively long time after feed termination. Coupled with post-NH
), which show almost no change in functional groups on the surface of the material, and post-NH
), the likely removal mechanism is simple hydrogen-bonding, likely with both adsorbed moisture as well as pendant amine groups.
CNCl microbreakthrough curves are illustrated in Figure
, and calculated loadings are summarized in Table

results, a clear trend is present: the CNCl loading decreases with increasing pelletization pressure. Under dry conditions, most of the materials exhibit traditional S-shaped breakthrough curves, indicating the formation of a wavefront through the materials; however, the UiO-66-NH

-100K sample shows immediate breakthrough, indicating poor diffusional properties to the active sites. The as-synthesized material exhibits a high CNCl loading, and in conjunction with the desorption profiles, the removal mechanism seems to be fairly strong, with the CNCl concentration dropping quickly after feed termination. However, under humid conditions, all samples show immediate breakthrough of CNCl, with a gradual increase to saturation. This behavior indicates that adsorbed water poisons the interaction/reaction with active sites within the UiO-66-NH
Figure 6. CNCl microbreakthrough curves under (left) dry and (right) humid conditions.
reveal that there is little change in the chemical modes present upon exposure to CNCl under both wet and dry conditions. However, the band observed at ν ≈ 2235 cm
exposed to CNCl under both dry and wet conditions represents a C≡N stretch. Because free CNCl shows a band at ν ≈ 2200 cm
, it is unclear whether the observed band represents CNCl in the pores of the MOF or a more complex interaction such as NH
···NC, similar to that witnessed between CNCl and OH groups by Kim et al.
In any case, some CNCl, or byproducts thereof, is present after the desorption step, indicating permanent removal.
Figure 7. Post-CNCl-exposure FTIR-ATR spectra for UiO-66-NH

-100K) show high CNCl uptake under dry conditions, ranging from 4.1 mol/kg (0.25 g/g) for the as-synthesized sample to 2.7 mol/kg (0.17 g/g) for the samples pressed at 25000 psi. Even under humid conditions, the actual capacity remains relatively high for multiple samples, albeit at the expense of mass transfer and reaction sites due to moisture poisoning.
Because of the high capacities demonstrated by the UiO-66-NH

material, scaling to larger quantities was conducted for the purpose of evaluation under conditions simulating individual protection filters. The sample pressed at 5000 psi was chosen because it demonstrated almost no degradation in performance as compared to the as-synthesized powder. As a comparison, breakthrough testing of a 3M broad-spectrum carbon was also conducted. The density of the UiO-66-NH
-5K sample is significantly lower than that of the carbon (Table S1,
), and the particle size distribution is skewed toward larger particles (Table S2,
and CNCl breakthrough curves for the two materials. Results show NH
begins to break through the packed bed of UiO-66-NH
-5K around 15 min, whereas the BSC material lasts over 20 min before NH
begins eluting. The breakthrough times were calculated to be 17.3 and 24.9 min for UiO-66-NH
-5K and BSC, respectively, to a concentration of 17 mg/m
. Of particular note is the shape of the NH
breakthrough curves. Whereas the curve through BSC is relatively sharp, going from 0 to over 200 mg/m
in less than 5 min, the curve through UiO-66-NH
-5K is much broader, taking approximately 10 min over the same concentration range. This behavior is typical of a material with high capacity but mass-transfer limitations of NH
going from the bulk phase (contaminated air stream) to the sorbent. One explanation for this behavior is the difference in particle size distribution (Table S2,
). As noted above, the average particle size of the UiO-66-NH
-5K sample is larger than that of the BSC material. The other potential cause of the diffusional limitations in UiO-66-NH
-5K is the pore size distribution. Whereas activated carbons generally have a heterogeneous pore structure consisting of meso- and macropores,

which act as transport pores for toxic chemicals, the UiO-66 materials are almost completely microporous, providing physical limitations to diffusion rates. Differential and cumulative pore volumes for the BSC and baseline UiO-66-NH
material are shown in Figure S3 (
). In all, however, the capacity for NH
removal is sufficiently high on UiO-66-NH
-5K compared to BSC. The challenge concentration was 1000 mg/m
-5K compared to BSC. The challenge concentration was 4000 mg/m
Similarly, the CNCl breakthrough curves indicate that the BSC provides much better removal than the UiO-66-NH
-5K material. Whereas BSC provides a CNCl breakthrough time of 14.8 min to 8 mg/m

), the chemical immediately penetrates the MOF, indicating that the amount of MOF used is less than the critical bed depth required to sufficiently remove CNCl. Although it is apparent that the MOF is capable of removing CNCl, the removal mechanism (adsorption + reaction) is sufficiently slow to cause breakthrough, once again likely due to diffusional limitations. With the larger particles, the critical bed depth under the conditions studied is likely significantly larger, resulting in immediate breakthrough. Furthermore, the kinetic diameter of CNCl (approximately 5.6 Å)
is similar to that of the UiO-66-NH
which likely further inhibits diffusion. Yet, even with this immediate breakthrough, the UiO-66-NH
shows significant capacity similar to that of the BSC, as the breakthrough curves to higher concentration levels are quite similar.
= a concentration-time variable denoting the dose of chemical.

was pressed at pressures ranging from 5000 to approximately 100000 psi to determine the effects on physical properties and chemical removal performance. It was determined that surface area and porosity decreased slightly at pressures up to 25000 psi, after which the structure degraded significantly. NH
and CNCl removals also dropped significantly as pressure increased. The material pressed at 5000 psi was scaled to large quantities for breakthrough testing against NH

and CNCl. The results indicate that the material provides significant capacity but lacks the mass-transfer kinetics necessary for use in a filter. This result likely stems from a lack of a hierarchical pore structure, as UiO-66-NH
is very microporous in nature, and further studies must be conducted to enhance diffusion characteristics of the material.

Information on density, particle size, ammonia microbreakthrough of UiO-66 variants, post-ammonia-exposure PXRD patterns, and pore size distribution. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at

Interactions of Ammonia with the Surface of Microporous Carbon Impregnated with Transition Metal Chlorides
Interactions of Ammonia with the Surface of Microporous Carbon Impregnated with Transition Metal Chlorides
Petit, Camille; Karwacki, Christopher; Peterson, Greg; Bandosz, Teresa J.

The BPL carbon samples impregnated with chlorides of copper, nickel, and zinc were used as ammonia adsorbents in dynamic conditions with various amts. of water present in the systems.  The initial and exhausted samples were characterized using adsorption of nitrogen, XRF, XRD, FTIR, SEM, and thermal anal.  The results indicate that metal chlorides are active centers for ammonia adsorption via formation of complexes.  Water enhances the amt. of ammonia adsorbed, promoting its dissolving into the film of water adsorbed in micropores and formation of NH4+ ions.  Even though the pore system of activated carbon provides spaces for dispersion of metals, it still contributes significantly to the amt. of ammonia adsorbed (about 80%) via dispersive forces.  The most efficient adsorbent for ammonia removal is the carbon impregnated with copper.  In this material the efficiency is governed by the amt. of copper introduced to the carbon and its dispersion on the surface.
Adsorption of Ammonia by Sulfuric Acid Treated Zirconium Hydroxide
Adsorption of Ammonia by Sulfuric Acid Treated Zirconium Hydroxide
Glover, T. Grant; Peterson, Gregory W.; DeCoste, Jared B.; Browe, Matthew A.

The adsorption of NH3 on Zr(OH)4, as well as Zr(OH)4 treated with H2SO4, were examd.  Treating Zr(OH)4 with H2SO4 gives a sulfate on the surface of the material, and that the sulfate contributes to the NH3 adsorption capacity through the formation of an ammonium sulfates species.  Calcination of Zr(OH)4 decreases the NH3 adsorption capacity of the material and limits the formation of sulfate species.  NMR and FTIR spectroscopy results are presented that show two distinct ammonium species on the surface of the material.  The adsorption capacity of the materials is a complex phenomenon that is impacted by the surface area, the S content, and the pH of the material.  Zr(OH)4, which is known to adsorb acidic gases, can be modified and used to adsorb basic gases.
Role of TEDA as an Activated Carbon Impregnant for the Removal of Cyanogen Chloride from Air Streams: Synergistic Effect with Cu(II)
Role of TEDA as an Activated Carbon Impregnant for the Removal of Cyanogen Chloride from Air Streams: Synergistic Effect with Cu(II)
Mahle, John J.; Peterson, Gregory W.; Schindler, Bryan J.; Smith, Philip B.; Rossin, Joseph A.; Wagner, George W.

The hydrolysis and fate of cyanogen chloride (CK) in the presence of triethylenediamine (TEDA), a widely used C impregnant, in aq. and non-aq. (acetonitrile) media was detd.  In the presence of water, anticipated TEDA substitution was not obsd.; rather, simple base-catalyzed (OH-) hydrolysis to cyanic acid (HOCN; unstable in water, decompg. to CO2 and NH3) was the major reaction, accompanied by a series of complex side reactions (not involving TEDA) forming several persistent compds.  Thus, the role of TEDA in the presence of water, is primarily a source of OH-.  CK substitution at TEDA was obsd. in acetonitrile, forming several complex, but quite different, species.  Studies examg. CK removal from humidified air by TEDA- and/or basic Cu2+-impregnated C (Cu2+ is another common c impregnant) were consistent with simple hydrolysis at the major CK-removal mechanism; no TEDA substitution was obsd. in the presence of humidity/water.  Considering the reaction stoichiometry apparent at CK break-through for impregnated carbons, the TEDA and Cu2+ combination was much more effective than the individual impregnants.  This synergism was attributed to dissoln. of basic Cu2+ by TEDA forming sol. complexes of the [Cu(TEDA)2(OH)(H2O)]- type in the C-adsorbed water layer, thus greatly increasing the dispersion and effectiveness of the basic Cu2+ impregnant.
Chemisorption of Cyanogen Chloride by Spinel Ferrite Magnetic Nanoparticles
Chemisorption of Cyanogen Chloride by Spinel Ferrite Magnetic Nanoparticles
Glover, T. Grant; DeCoste, Jared B.; Sabo, Daniel; Zhang, Z. John

Spinel ferrite magnetic nanoparticles, MnFe2O4, NiFe2O4, and CoFe2O4, were synthesized and used as gas-phase adsorbents for the removal of cyanogen chloride from dry air.  Fixed-bed adsorption breakthrough expts. show adsorption wave behavior at the leading edge of the breakthrough curve that is not typical of phys. adsorbed species.  Fourier transform IR spectroscopy indicated that CK reacted with the spinel ferrite surface and formed a carbamate species.  The reaction was shown to be a function of the hydroxyl groups and adsorbed water on the surface of the particles as well as the metallic compn. of the particles.  The surface reaction decreases the remnant and satn. magnetism of the MnFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 particles by approx. 25%.
Gas Adsorption Properties of the Ternary ZnO/CuO/CuCl
Impregnated Activated Carbon System for Multigas Respirator Applications Assessed through Combinatorial Methods and Dynamic Adsorption Studies
Gas Adsorption Properties of the Ternary ZnO/CuO/CuCl2 Impregnated Activated Carbon System for Multigas Respirator Applications Assessed through Combinatorial Methods and Dynamic Adsorption Studies
Romero, JenniferV.; Smith, Jock W. H.; Sullivan, Braden M.; Mallay, Matthew G.; Croll, Lisa M.; Reynolds, Judy A.; Andress, Carrie; Simon, Monika; Dahn, Jeff R.

A ternary library of 64 ZnO/CuO/CuCl2 impregnated activated C samples was synthesized and automatically screened using a combinatorial method (combi).  The ability of the samples to adsorb toxic gases was gravimetrically screened.  A stoichiometric ratio of reaction (SRR) between moles of toxicant and total moles of impregnant was obtained using the calcd. mass increase of samples following chemisorption; a high SRR indicated highly efficient toxicant removal.  Combi samples which exhibited good dry SO2 and NH3 adsorption, prepd. in bulk using the incipient wetness method, were evaluated for multi-gas respirator function by dynamic adsorption studies of SO2, NH3, HCN, and C6H12 gases in dry or humid conditions at ambient temp.  Bulk samples displayed equiv. gas adsorption capacities when exposed to the different challenge gases, indicating the value of the combi method for initial screening.  Cu2Cl(OH)3 was identified to be a potential multi-gas adsorbent.
Gas Adsorption on a Ternary ZnO/CuO/CuCl
Impregnated Activated Carbon Evaluated Using Combinatorial Methods
SO2 and NH3 Gas Adsorption on a Ternary ZnO/CuO/CuCl2 Impregnated Activated Carbon Evaluated Using Combinatorial Methods
Romero, Jennifer V.; Smith, Jock W. H.; Sullivan, Braden M.; Croll, Lisa M.; Dahn, J. R.

Ternary libraries of 64 ZnO/CuO/CuCl2 impregnated activated carbon samples were prepd. on untreated or HNO3-treated carbon and evaluated for their SO2 and NH3 gas adsorption properties gravimetrically using a combinatorial method.  CuCl2 is shown to be a viable substitute for HNO3 and some compns. of ternary ZnO/CuO/CuCl2 impregnated carbon samples prepd. on untreated carbon provided comparable SO2 and NH3 gas removal capacities to the materials prepd. on HNO3-treated carbon.  Through combinatorial methods, it was detd. that the use of HNO3 in this multigas adsorbent formulation can be avoided.
Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal–Organic Frameworks
Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features.  All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions.  Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit.  The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials.  But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake.  The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs.  Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
Metal–Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Capacity for Storage of Carbon Dioxide at Room Temperature
Millward, Andrew R.; Yaghi, Omar M.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) show high CO2 storage capacity at room temp.  Gravimetric CO2 isotherms for MOF-2, MOF-505, Cu3(BTC)2, MOF-74, IRMOF-11, IRMOF-3, IRMOF-6, IRMOF-1 and MOF-177 are reported up to 42 bar.  Type I isotherms are found in all cases except for MOFs based on Zn4O(O2C)6 clusters, which reveal a sigmoidal isotherm.  The various pressures of the isotherm steps correlate with increasing pore size, which indicates potential for gas sepns.  The amine functionality of the IRMOF-3 pore shows evidence of relatively increased affinity for CO2.  Capacities qual. scale with surface area and range from 3.2 mmol/g for MOF-2 to 33.5 mmol/g (320 cm3(STP)/cm3, 147 wt %) for MOF-177, the highest CO2 capacity of any porous material reported.
Aldehyde Self-Condensation Catalysis by Aluminum Aminoterephthalate Metal–Organic Frameworks Modified with Aluminum Isopropoxide
Aldehyde Self-Condensation Catalysis by Aluminum Aminoterephthalate Metal-Organic Frameworks Modified with Aluminum Isopropoxide
Bromberg, Lev; Su, Xiao; Hatton, T. Alan

Porous materials based on aluminum(III) 2-aminoterephthalate metal org. frameworks (MOFs NH2MIL101(Al) and NH2MIL53(Al)) and their composites with aluminum isopropoxide (Al-i-Pro) are studied as sorbents of vapors of volatile aldehydes and catalysts of acetaldehyde dimerization to Et acetate via the Tischenko reaction.  MOF/Al-i-Pro composites obtained by simple impregnation of the MOFs with hydrocarbon solns. of Al-i-Pro are stable due to the formation of bonds between the MOF carbonyls and Al-i-Pro.  The specific BET surface areas of the MOFs NH2MIL101(Al) and NH2MIL53(Al) ranged from 1650 to 1980 and 670-780 M2/g, resp., and were lowered 6-12-fold by impregnation of Al-i-Pro into the MOF pores.  However, the acetaldehyde and acrolein uptake by the MOF/Al-i-Pro composites from satd. vapor atm. is comparable to that of their resp. parent MOFs and exceeds the aldehyde uptake of activated carbon or mol. sieves.  Due of the propensity of the Al-i-Pro to catalyze dimerization of acetaldehyde to Et acetate, the latter is the main product of the reaction between acetaldehyde and MOF/Al-i-Pro materials, whereas crotonaldehyde is found in the products of the acetaldehyde self-condensation on the parent MOF NH2MIL101(Al).  The kinetics of acetaldehyde dimerization into Et acetate catalyzed by NH2MIL101(Al)/Al-i-Pro in deuterated benzene at room temp. are measured over three consecutive cycles.  The apparent second-order reaction rate is 5.2 × 10-5 M-1s-1, which is of the same order as in the analogous reaction catalyzed by a homogeneous soln. of Al-i-Pro.  The MOF/Al-i-Pro materials are proven to be recyclable heterogeneous catalysts.
Catalyst with Synergistic Stability and Reactivity: A Polyoxometalate–Metal Organic Framework for Aerobic Decontamination
A Multiunit Catalyst with Synergistic Stability and Reactivity: A Polyoxometalate-Metal Organic Framework for Aerobic Decontamination
Song, Jie; Luo, Zhen; Britt, David K.; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Yaghi, Omar M.; Hardcastle, Kenneth I.; Hill, Craig L.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A combination of polyanion size and charge allows the Keggin-type polyoxometalate (POM), [CuPW11O39]5-, a catalyst for some air-based org. oxidns., to fit snuggly in the pores of MOF-199 (HKUST-1), a metal-org. framework (MOF) with the POM countercations residing in alternative pores.  This close matching of POM diam. and MOF pore size in this POM-MOF material, [Cu3(C9H3O6)2]4[{(CH3)4N}4CuPW11O39H] (1), results in a substantial synergistic stabilization of both the MOF and the POM.  In addn., this heretofore undocumented POM-MOF interaction results in a dramatic increase in the catalytic turnover rate of the POM for air-based oxidns.  While 1 catalyzes the rapid chemo- and shape-selective oxidn. of thiols to disulfides and, more significantly, the rapid and sustained removal of toxic H2S via H2S + 1/2 O2 → 1/8 S8 + H2O (4000 turnovers in <20 h), the POM or the MOF alone is catalytically slow or inactive.  Three arguments are consistent with the catalytic reactions taking place inside the pores.  POM activation by encapsulation in the MOF likely involves electrostatic interactions between the two components resulting in a higher redn. potential of the POM.

Liu, Jian; Wang, Yu; Benin, Annabelle I.; Jakubczak, Paulina; Willis, Richard R.; Le Van, M. Douglas

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted intense research interest because of their permanent porous structures, huge surface areas, and potential applications as novel adsorbents and catalysts.  In order to provide a basis for consideration of MOFs for removal of carbon dioxide from gases contg. water vapor, such as flue gas, we have studied adsorption equil. of CO2, H2O vapor, and their mixts. and also rates of CO2 adsorption in two MOFs: HKUST-1 (CuBTC) and Ni/DOBDC (CPO-27-Ni or Ni/MOF-74).  The MOFs were synthesized via solvothermal methods, and the as-synthesized products were solvent exchanged and regenerated before expts.  Pure component adsorption equil. and CO2/H2O binary adsorption equil. were studied using a volumetric system.  The effects of H2O adsorption on CO2 adsorption for both MOF samples were detd., and the results for 5A and NaX zeolites were included for comparison.  The hydrothermal stabilities for the two MOFs over the course of repetitive measurements of H2O and CO2/H2O mixt. equil. were also studied.  CO2 adsorption rates from helium for the MOF samples were investigated by using a unique concn.-swing frequency response (CSFR) system.  Mass transfer into the MOFs is rapid with the controlling resistance found to be macropore diffusion, and rate parameters were established for the mechanism.

Peralta, David; Barthelet, Karin; Perez-Pellitero, Javier; Chizallet, Celine; Chaplais, Gerald; Simon-Masseron, Angelique; Pirngruber, Gerhard D.

The sepn. of xylene isomers is one of the most difficult sepns. in petrochem.  Adsorbents have to preferentially adsorb para or meta isomers, but there are only a few zeolites which fulfill the criteria of selectivity and adsorption capacity.  The authors evaluate 2 metal-org. frameworks (MOF) with coordinatively unsatd. metal sites (cus), i.e., CPO-27-Ni and HKUST-1, in the adsorption and sepn. of p-xylene, m-xylene, and o-xylene in the gas phase.  The results are compared with those of the zeolite NaY.  CPO-27-Ni and HKUST-1 are both ortho-selective adsorbents, but mol. simulations indicate that the reasons for the ortho selectivity are quite different.  The CPO-27-Ni structure is intrinsically ortho selective, and the ortho selectivity is further enhanced by electrostatic effects.  HKUST-1, however, is intrinsically (weakly) para selective but the para selectivity is overcompensated by electrostatic effects, which overall leads to a slight preference for the ortho isomer adsorption.  The insights in the adsorption behavior of xylenes that are provided by this study provide useful guidelines in the quest for para-selective MOFs materials.
Mixtures in the Highly Flexible MIL-53(Cr) MOF

Hamon, Lomig; Llewellyn, Philip L.; Devic, Thomas; Ghoufi, Aziz; Clet, Guillaume; Guillerm, Vincent; Pirngruber, Gerhard D.; Maurin, Guillaume; Serre, Christian; Driver, Gordon; van Beek, Wouter; Jolimaitre, Elsa; Vimont, Alexandre; Daturi, Marco; Ferey, Gerard
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The present study attempts to understand the use of the flexible porous chromium terephthalate Cr(OH)(O2C-C6H4-CO2) denoted MIL-53(Cr) (MIL = Material from Institut Lavoisier) for the sepn. of mixts. of CO2 and CH4 at ambient temp.  The coadsorption of CO2 and CH4 was studied by a variety of different techniques.  In situ synchrotron x-ray powder diffraction allowed study of the breathing of the solid upon adsorption of the gas mixts. and simultaneously measured Raman spectra yielded an estn. of the adsorbed quantities of CO2 and CH4, as well as a quantification of the fraction of the narrow pore (NP) and the large pore (LP) form of MIL-53.  Quant. coadsorption data were then measured by gravimetry and by breakthrough curves.  In addn., computer simulation was performed to calc. the compn. of the adsorbed phase in comparison with exptl. equil. isotherms and breakthrough results.  The body of results shows that the coadsorption of CO2 and CH4 leads to a similar breathing of MIL-53(Cr) as with pure CO2.  The breathing is mainly controlled by the partial pressure of CO2, but increasing the CH4 content progressively decreases the transformation of LP to NP.  CH4 seems to be excluded from the NP form, which is filled exclusively by CO2 mols.  The consequences in terms of CO2/CH4 selectivity and the possible use of MIL-53(Cr) in a PSA process are discussed.

Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

Benchmarks have been established for the performance of six metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and isoreticular MOFs (IRMOFs, which have the same underlying topol. as MOF-5), MOF-5, IRMOF-3, MOF-74, MOF-177, MOF-199, and IRMOF-62, as selective adsorbents for eight harmful gases: sulfur dioxide, ammonia, chlorine, tetrahydrothiophene, benzene, dichloromethane, ethylene oxide, and carbon monoxide.  Kinetic breakthrough measurements are used to det. the calcd. dynamic adsorption capacity of each "benchmark" MOF for each gas.  The capacity of each MOF is compared to that of a sample of Calgon BPL activated carbon.  We find that pore functionality plays a dominant role in detg. the dynamic adsorption performance of MOFs.  MOFs featuring reactive functionality outperform BPL carbon in all but one case and exhibit high dynamic adsorption capacities up to 35% by wt.

and Its Characterization by MAS NMR

Adsorption equil. and NMR expts. were performed to study the adsorption and interactions of ammonia with metal-org. framework HKUST-1, or Cu3(BTC)2 (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate).  Ammonia capacities detd. from chem. breakthrough measurements show significantly higher uptake capacities than from adsorption alone, suggesting a stronger interaction involving a potential reaction with the Cu3(BTC)2 framework.  Indeed, 1H MASNMR reveals that a major disruption of the relatively simple spectrum of Cu3(BTC)2 occurs to generate a composite spectrum consistent with Cu(OH)2 and (NH4)3BTC species under humid conditions-the anticipated products of a copper(II) carboxylate reacted with limited ammonia.  These species are not detected under dry conditions; however, reaction stoichiometry combined with XRD results suggests the partial formation of an indeterminate diammine copper(II) complex with some residual Cu3(BTC)2 structure retained. Cu(II)-induced paramagnetic shifts exhibited by various species in 1H and 13C MASNMR spectra are consistent with model compds. and previous literature.  Although results show extensive ammonia capacity of Cu3(BTC)2, much of the capacity is due to reaction with the structure itself, causing a permanent loss in porosity and structural integrity.

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) can incorporate a large no. of different functionalities on linking groups in a way that mixes the linker, rather than forming sep. domains. The backbone (Zn oxide and phenylene units) of these structures is ordered, but the distribution of functional groups is disordered.  The complex arrangements of several functional groups within the pores can lead to properties that are not simply linear sums of those of the pure components. Journal of the American Chemical Society

Postsynthetic ligand and metal ion exchange (PSE) processes readily occur in several inert metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), including zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs).  Ligand exchange can occur between solid samples, as was demonstrated under relatively mild conditions with two robust, topol. distinct MOFs, MIL-53(Al) and MIL-68(In). These PSE reactions were monitored and the products characterized by a no. of techniques, including aerosol time-of-flight mass spectrometry, which permits single-particle compositional anal.  To show the potential synthetic utility of this approach, the PSE process was used to prep. the first Ti(IV) analog of the robust UiO-66(Zr) framework.  Finally, expts. to rule out mechanisms other than PSE (i.e., aggregation, dissoln./recrystn.) were performed.  PSE, of either ligands or cations, is common even with highly robust MOFs such as UiO-66(Zr), MILs, and ZIFs. Kim, Min; Cahill, John F.; Su, Yongxuan; Prather, Kimberly A.; Cohen, Seth M.

Herein, the authors report that the exchange of ligands from an intact metal-org. framework (MOF) can be exploited as a means to introduce functionalized ligands into MOFs under mild conditions.  Ligand exchange can occur with 'inert' Zr(IV)-based UiO-66 MOFs in a solvent dependent manner.  The authors call this process postsynthetic exchange (PSE) and show that it provides access to MOFs that are not readily prepd. in high quality by solvothermal methods.  Ligand exchange can occur between UiO-66 MOFs as monitored by aerosol time-of-flight mass spectrometry (ATOFMS).  ATOFMS was used to analyze the chem. compn. of microcryst. MOFs on the single particle level, providing information not available through bulk anal.  PSE is an important postsynthetic approach to the modification of MOFs, and the ligand exchange revealed by ATOFMS requires a reevaluation of the assumed 'stability' of even the most robust MOFs.
A New Zirconium Inorganic Building Brick Forming Metal Organic Frameworks with Exceptional Stability
A new zirconium inorganic building brick forming metal organic frameworks with exceptional stability
Cavka Jasmina Hafizovic; Jakobsen Soren; Olsbye Unni; Guillou Nathalie; Lamberti Carlo; Bordiga Silvia; Lillerud Karl Petter
Journal of the American Chemical Society

Porous crystals are strategic materials with industrial applications within petrochemistry, catalysis, gas storage, and selective separation.  Their unique properties are based on the molecular-scale porous character.  However, a principal limitation of zeolites and similar oxide-based materials is the relatively small size of the pores, typically in the range of medium-sized molecules, limiting their use in pharmaceutical and fine chemical applications.  Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) provided a breakthrough in this respect.  New MOFs appear at a high and an increasing pace, but the appearances of new, stable inorganic building bricks are rare.  Here we present a new zirconium-based inorganic building brick that allows the synthesis of very high surface area MOFs with unprecedented stability.  The high stability is based on the combination of strong Zr-O bonds and the ability of the inner Zr6-cluster to rearrange reversibly upon removal or addition of mu3-OH groups, without any changes in the connecting carboxylates.  The weak thermal, chemical, and mechanical stability of most MOFs is probably the most important property that limits their use in large scale industrial applications.  The Zr-MOFs presented in this work have the toughness needed for industrial applications; decomposition temperature above 500 degrees C and resistance to most chemicals, and they remain crystalline even after exposure to 10 tons/cm2 of external pressure.

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with the Zr6O4(OH)4 secondary building unit (SBU) were of particular interest for potential com. and industrial uses because they can be easily tailored and are reported to be chem. and thermally stable.  However, there are significant changes in chem. and thermal stability of Zr6O4(OH)4 MOFs with the incorporation of different org. linkers.  As the no. of arom. rings is increased from one to two in 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate (UiO-66, ZrMOF-BDC) and 4,4'-biphenyl dicarboxylate (UiO-67, ZrMOF-BPDC), the Zr6O4(OH)4 SBU becomes more susceptible to chem. degrdn. by water and hydrochloric acid.  Also, as the linker is replaced with 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylate (ZrMOF-BIPY) the chem. stability decreases further as the MOF is susceptible to chem. breakdown by protic chems. such as methanol and isopropanol.  The results reported here bring into question the superior structural stability of the UiO-67 analogs as reported by others.  Also, the degrdn. mechanisms proposed here may be applied to other classes of MOFs contg. arom. dicarboxylate org. linkers, to predict their structural stability upon exposure to solvents.

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with metal-carboxylate bonds, including Cu-BTC (HKUST-1), Mg-MOF-74 (Mg/DOBDC), and UiO-66, have been shown to have varying degrees of water stability.  The MOF degrdn. at several temp. and humidity conditions over the course of 28 days was investigated.  At conditions of 90% relative humidity (RH) and 25°C, water uptake for Cu-BTC is shown to be higher than at 90% RH and 40°C, causing the degrdn. of the inner structure of Cu-BTC to occur more readily at the lower temp.  However the external surfaces of Cu-BTC degrade more readily, as shown through SEM images, at conditions of 90% RH and 40°C.  Mg-MOF-74 has a nearly complete loss of surface area after just one day of exposure to each of the conditions studied, however the PXRD patterns show only a change in the [100] peak.  A mechanism for the degrdn. of Mg-MOF-74 involving a 6-coordinate Mg intermediate which leaves the 1-dimensional channels of Mg-MOF-74 intact is offered.  UiO-66 is stable to each of the aging conditions for the full 28 days.

It is important to remove flue gas CO2, considered a main cause of global warming.  CO2/N2 sepn. by novel adsorbents is a promising method to reduce CO2 emissions.  The effect of water on CO2 adsorption and CO2/N2 selectivity is crit. to enable adsorbent utilization in practical applications.  Ni/DOBDC (Ni-MOF-74 or CPO-27-Ni) was synthesized using a solvothermal reaction, and a pellet sample was used in a fixed-bed CO2/N2 break-through study with and without water.  The Ni/DOBDC pellet has high CO2 capacity (3.74 mol/kg at 0.15 bar) and high CO2/N2 selectivity (38), much higher than those of reported metal-org. frameworks (MOF) and zeolites under dry conditions.  Trace amts. of water affected CO2 adsorption capacity and CO2/N2 selectivity by Ni/DOBDC; however, Ni/DOBDC retained a significant CO2 capacity (2.2 mol/kg) and a CO2/N2 selectivity (22) at 0.15 bar CO2 with 3% relative humidity water.  Results indicated a promising future for Ni/DOBDC use in flue gas CO2 removal.

Bulk powd. MOF-177 was mech. compressed to prep. monoliths with bulk densities >3 times its crystallog. d.  The excess and total gravimetric and volumetric H storage capacities of the compressed material were measured over a pressure range of 0-13 MPa at 77 K and at room temp.  The max. excess volumetric H storage capacity of these monoliths at ∼6 MPa and 77 K is 25.8±1.2 g/L, a 78% increase of that of powd. bulk MOF-177 and 80% of the theor. max. excess volumetric H storage capacity predicted from the material's crystallog. d.  The monoliths show diminishing excess gravimetric capacity with increasing d. which is attributed to their decreasing micropore vol., which in turn stems from the progressive collapse of MOF-177 crystals to an amorphous phase when they are subjected to densification.  A modified Dubinin-Astakhov (DA) model was adapted to describe the excess gravimetric adsorption of samples with varying bulk densities.  The total volumetric capacity of monoliths prepd. from MOF-177 is 48.0±2.1 g/L at 13 MPa and 77 K if a complete storage system that does not decrease this capacity by >20% is designed, it can meet the DOE 2015 volumetric system target at 77 K. Liq.-phase adsorption of phenol by activated carbons prepd. from a bituminous coal was investigated.  The carbon prepn. consisted of carbonization of the oxidized or the unoxidized coal followed by activation in CO2 to various extents of burnoff.  It was obsd. from the exptl. results that BET surface area and pore vol. are important factors in detg. the adsorptive capacity of the activated carbons.  The Langmuir model yields a fairly good fit to the adsorption isotherms, indicating a monolayer adsorption of phenol onto these carbons.  The amt. of phenol adsorbed per unit surface area, corresponding to complete coverage of the adsorptive sites, decreases with the extent of burnoff and with the particle size of the carbon.  The decrease can be attributed to the increase in diffusion path.  It was found that the adsorptive capacity decreases with the temp. for the carbon prepd. from the unoxidized coal, while it increases for the carbons from the oxidized coal.  This difference can be attributed to different populations of oxygen functional groups on the carbon surfaces.  According to the Langmuir model, the adsorption of phenol on these carbons was found to be to an endothermic process.

This work presents an exptl. study of H2O adsorption in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) at room temp. and up to 90% relative humidity.
